summary:
The Security Council:

Acknowledging the importance of drawing on best practices and lessons learned from other missions, 

Establishing the United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (UNMISS) for an initial period of one year with up to 7,000 military personnel, 900 civilian police personnel, and a civilian component.

 Mandate of UNMISS: 
- Consolidate peace and security 
- Help establish conditions for development 

Tasks: 

(a) Support peace consolidation, state-building, and economic development 

- Provide good offices, advice, and support on political transition, governance 

- Promote popular participation in political processes 

(b) Support conflict prevention, mitigation, and resolution, and protect civilians 

- Exercise good offices, confidence-building, and facilitation 

- Establish early warning capacity 

- Monitor, investigate, verify, and report on human rights 

- Advise and assist Government in fulfilling its responsibility to protect civilians 

- Deter violence, protect civilians under imminent threat 

- Provide security for UN and humanitarian personnel 

(c) Support capacity development for security, rule of law, and justice 

- Support security sector reform, rule of law, and justice sector development 

- Support national disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration strategy
Here is a concise summary of the Security Council document 1996 (2011):

The Security Council authorizes the United Nations Mission in the Republic of South Sudan (UNMISS) to:

* Protect civilians, including women and children
* Support the Government of the Republic of South Sudan in developing a military justice system
* Strengthen the capacity of the Republic of South Sudan Police Services
* Facilitate a protective environment for children affected by armed conflict
* Support de-mining activities

UNMISS is authorized to use all necessary means to carry out its protection mandate.

The Government of Sudan and the Government of the Republic of South Sudan are requested to:
* Propose modalities for implementation of the 29 June agreement on border monitoring
* Cooperate fully with UNMISS

All parties are demanded to:
* Cease all forms of violence and human rights abuses against civilians
* Allow full, safe and unhindered access of relief personnel to all those in need
